repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
This fixes a few recently reported compiler crashes. It should possibly be 3 separate PRs and I can split it up if needed.

Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3843 - allow creation of wrapper functions with memoryview arguments
Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3820 - report error when return type cannot be deduced from fused arguments
Fixes https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/3830 - don't allow annotation types to set the type of cdef class class-level attributes

comment_data.body:
I guess the call in line 3229 of the same file is the culprit here. There is a special-case for `for_display` just below. The question is how `pyrex=True` should behave there (read: the declaration code in a Cython-specific context).

What happens if you create multiple wrappers for functions with slightly different memoryview arguments? Do we build suitable C names for all of them?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -695,7 +695,6 @@ def is_complete(self):
     def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
             for_display = 0, dll_linkage = None, pyrex = 0):
         # XXX: we put these guards in for now...
-        assert not pyrex

comment_data.body: And probably also if we decide to allow the annotation syntax for defining cdef attributes. That's not entirely out of focus.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1997,6 +1997,11 @@ def declare_from_annotation(self, env, as_target=False):
             atype = unspecified_type if as_target and env.directives['infer_types'] != False else py_object_type
         if atype.is_fused and env.fused_to_specific:
             atype = atype.specialize(env.fused_to_specific)
+        if as_target and env.is_c_class_scope and not atype.is_pyobject:
+            # TODO: this will need revising slightly for cdef dataclasses when implemented

comment_data.body: That suggests to me that this might not be the right place to do this. Can't we detect this earlier? E.g. when analysing the function signature?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,6 +140,18 @@ def copy_cdef(self, env):
         for cname, fused_to_specific in permutations:
             copied_node = copy.deepcopy(self.node)
 
+            # unlike for the argument types, specializing the return type can fail, so tentatively
+            # try it here and produce an error message if it fails.
+            # specialize can also go through layers of pointers/const which makes anything other
+            # than "try...except" difficult

comment_data.body:
The call in line 3229 is the culprit.

Multiple wrappers for functions create multiple wrappers with the same name that all conflict with each other. Adding `for_display = for_display or pyrex` creates something that compiles (but probably doesn't really do what `pyrex` implies it should). I'll come back to this in the individual PR.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -695,7 +695,6 @@ def is_complete(self):
     def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
             for_display = 0, dll_linkage = None, pyrex = 0):
         # XXX: we put these guards in for now...
-        assert not pyrex

comment_data.body:
It probably could be done earlier but I think the problem would be the same - to work out if it specializes then you have to duplicate most of the specialization logic in PyrexTypes.

I wonder if it'd be better if `specialize` returned `error_type` rather than raising an exception to allow for "safe" checks that something specializes?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,6 +140,18 @@ def copy_cdef(self, env):
         for cname, fused_to_specific in permutations:
             copied_node = copy.deepcopy(self.node)
 
+            # unlike for the argument types, specializing the return type can fail, so tentatively
+            # try it here and produce an error message if it fails.
+            # specialize can also go through layers of pointers/const which makes anything other
+            # than "try...except" difficult

comment_data.body: `pyrex=True` is usually very similar to `for_display=True`, since both target the Cython code level. See the comment near the top of the file in `class PyrexType`. Can't say right now what a good escaped version of a memoryview declarations for use in a C name should look like. Probably needs some trial and error.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -695,7 +695,6 @@ def is_complete(self):
     def declaration_code(self, entity_code,
             for_display = 0, dll_linkage = None, pyrex = 0):
         # XXX: we put these guards in for now...
-        assert not pyrex

comment_data.body: Isn't it an issue whenever a fused type occurs in the return type that isn't used in any of the arguments? Or are there legitimate use cases for that as well?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -140,6 +140,18 @@ def copy_cdef(self, env):
         for cname, fused_to_specific in permutations:
             copied_node = copy.deepcopy(self.node)
 
+            # unlike for the argument types, specializing the return type can fail, so tentatively
+            # try it here and produce an error message if it fails.
+            # specialize can also go through layers of pointers/const which makes anything other
+            # than "try...except" difficult

commit.message: Allow wrappers to be generated for functions with memoryviews (3843)
Produce error for unspecializable fused return type
Fixed Compiler crash with annotated cdef class attributes

title: Fix various compiler crashes
